title: Friday, 30th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Ok! Welcome to ML

PM

This feels like an important session

PM

Not that all our ML sessions are not important

11:01 am
PM

But this one, especially so

PM

We're gonna save Deutsche Bank

PM

Yes, really

11:01 am
PM

buy Deutsche Bank

PM

Buy it now

BE

Steady.

11:01 am
PM

Don't hesitate

PM

Deep deep value

PM

Deep value hiding in plain sight

11:02 am
PM

This is Deutsche

PM

And Bryce has a plan

PM

The Elder Plan

11:02 am
PM

Gonna save what should be Europe's biggest and strongest financial institution

PM

Let me get a couple of charts up

PM

Here's the stock price near term

11:03 am
PM

http://imgur.com/bVDddki

BE

PM

http://imgur.com/igacNHn

11:04 am
PM

And longer term

BE

PM

The Elder plan, when enacted will prob see the price double

11:04 am
PM

I say when not if

BE

Hell's teeth, Murph. You might be building this up a wee bit much.

PM

omg smile

11:05 am
BE

Look, I'm not smart. I really don't know what I'm talking about. I want to make that as crystal clear as I possibly can.

BE

However, I had my bi-annual thought this morning.

BE

Why don't banks price their rights issues at a premium to market?

11:06 am
PM

Why indeed.

PM

It's simples, but that's the beauty of it

BE

So, banking's unique in corporate terms because it's a confidence trick on capital levels. We know that.

11:06 am
BE

I see no downside to DB raising capital at TNAV, or close to, providong its 80% institutional shareholder base were onboard with the concept.

BE

They'd be crazy not to back this, because it'd rerate their existing holdings by an order of magnitude disproportionate to the cost of buying new equity at a premium.

BE

And the actual process of raising cash would take, what, three months start to finish?

11:07 am
PM

Absolutely

BE

Banking is mostly just a trick of confidence in capital, it's highly likely that today's premium would become a discount by the time of the shareholder vote.

PM

For investors, the exercise would pay for itself

11:07 am
BE

Dan Davies wrote an excellent column overnight pointing out that the real damage to Deutsche right now is to the franchise.

BE

There are no real doubts about its liquidity.

BE

And the only serious question on capital relates to who's going to be on the hook for the recap, and at what price.

11:08 am
BE

But the confidence-trick thing means DB can't respond properly to these stupid crisis headlines that have put shares into a self-fulfilling dilution spiral.

BE

So why are we assuming that a cash call would need to be priced from this weird starting point?

BE

If there's a general agreement that the current market price is distorted by a kind of escalating hysteria, and raising cash will calm that hysteria, why price the new equity at a discount to the hysteria price?

11:08 am
BE

I just don't get it.

PM

It's because no one's thought of it Bryce

PM

I absolutely expect them to send you a fat check when they pick up this idea

11:09 am
PM

Here's the top ten shareholder list

PM

http://imgur.com/miQmzar

BE

Look, I refuse to believe no-one's thought of this. I refer both you and the readers to my earlier point that, if I lost five IQ points, I'd probably be reclassified as a potato.

11:10 am
BE

Nevertheless, here's my plan.

BE

I can send John Cryan the envelope I've written it on, if he likes.

BE

One-for-one rights at €15.

11:10 am
BE

As in today, right now. Immediately.

BE

Here's my working.

PM

thumbs up

11:11 am
BE

DB's tangible book value is €50bn, which the consensus sees as remaining stable over the next few years, give or take a billion or two.

BE

It also has a €7bn capital shortfall to hit the longer term CET1 targets.

BE

Then there's the worst-case-scenario of a $14bn DOJ fine, for which it's under provisioned.

11:11 am
BE

For belt and braces purposes here, let's say DB could use €20bn of new cash against a market cap today of about €14bn.

BE

So what should happen here is that DB raises €20bn with a one-for-one rights at €15 a share?

PM

(Teh fine is just the result of some Chuck Rhoades-wanna be)

11:12 am
BE

That'd be a 40 per cent premium to today's market price, but it'd also be a near 60 per cent discount to TBV.

BE

Which was approximately its valuation before the DOJ fine landed.

BE

The result of a successful cash call at premium would be a bank with no capital shortfall

11:12 am
BE

And with €12bn or so that backstops its DOJ liabilitiy, and can be returned to shareholders in time.

BE

Even accepting that DB's return on equity has been woeful for two decades and its transparency is not exactly exemplary, a valuation of 0.4 times for a bank still seems extreme.

BE

(Note that Morgan Stanley, Goldman, BOA, etc trade at around TBV. UBS is at 1.2x TBV. JPM's 1.4x.)

11:13 am
BE

Tell me where I'm wrong here? What's the flaw in my logic? Because there must be one.

PM

You're not wrong

PM

Buy Deutsche bank now -- e10.44 asking price on my screen

11:14 am
PM

This is*Deutsche Bank*. It's not going under

PM

It's not going to fall under state control

PM

It underpins the Germany car industry

11:14 am
PM

buy buy buy

BE

This is not what I'm recommending

PM

I am

11:15 am
BE

I'm just saying that the problem's fixable if we treat banks as what they are, which are terrible but systemically important businesses that eat capital just to keep swimming

BE

So why don't investors agree to give them capital at a price that supports this confidence trick rather than undermines it?

BE

Ah, whatever.

11:17 am
PM

The Elder Plan. You read it here first.

undefined
BE

So, I see the FTSE's down 1.2% on my DB rescue plan.

11:18 am
BE

Fair enough. Can't argue.

BE

Down 82 points at 6837.

BE

Capita leading us down again, post yesterday's warning.

11:19 am
PM

Blimey, it's off another 5.5%

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 654.50, down 43.5 (-6.23%), High: 691.00, Low: 653.50, Volume: 3.43m
BE

You know I said yesterday about the warning reviving the quality of earnings question, and the sometimes odd ways that Capita adds up things like organic growth?

11:19 am
BE

Well, that's where we are now.

BE

Panmure incoming, to say "we don't know what's going on because management won't tell us"

BE

Our anti-consensus Sell case on CPI in Jan’16 was predicated on four concerns
that, we contested, made the shares far riskier than at any point hitherto. We
said that CPI felt “increasingly like the last man standing”. Not anymore. The
shares fell throughout 1H16, leading us, incorrectly, to believe that those
concerns might be in the price. We were wrong. As, it would appear, was
almost everyone else. We sat through the excruciating, hour-long analyst call
post the profit warning yesterday; a call that addressed precisely none of these
four issues. So let’s revisit each in turn, in the light of our 8% cut to 2017 EPS.

11:21 am
BE

Michael Donnelly's the analyst here.

BE

Balance Sheet P&L disconnect: We highlighted that CPI’s goodwill mkt cap is c.2x the
level of the peer average. We believed, and continue to believe, that “IT services”
goodwill may be at risk, and noted the worrying 9% (£71m) fall in 2014 of the largest
and most opaque category of goodwill. Capitalized software increased six-fold
proportionally since 2013 potentially flattering historical margins by c.50bps. And guess
what? The profit warning cites its tech reselling business as the major cause of the
slowdown. The asset remains overvalued and – we believe – will be impaired in due
course. Just as happened with L&P. This will be badly received by the market for two
reasons. Firstly, it renders future ROCE metrics and guidance meaningless just as the
market has shifted to focussing to ROCE. Secondly, given the overwhelming
preponderance of tech businesses that CPI has acquired since 2008, it puts at risk the
quality of the acquired growth, now that organic growth has all but disappeared. A
further point that is going to be done to death by other analysts guessing when the
rights issue is coming, is that CPI has operating leases that we value at £430-530m
(discounting at 7%-1.5%), so – if capitalised – they increase reported net debt by c.25%.

BE

Quality of earnings falling: The market gets the falling ROCE-WACC on flat(“ish”)
margins with inconsistent organic growth and proportionally rising exceptionals, but
doesn’t yet get, in our view, the potential c.£260m “cash deceit”, after CPI stopped
replacing its assets post c.2008. We visited the finance director recently who told us
that “this didn’t feel like an underinvested business” Repairing this could make FCF
growth negative. We model only c.3% FCF CAGR (2015-2018), assuming c.3% organic
CAGR and 4.1% of revenues spent as capex. FCF growth falls to zero if we only
increase our capex assumption to 4.7%, well within the bounds of forecast error.

11:21 am
BE

Acquisitions are very, very worrying: CPI’s £412m attempt to buy the accrual-heavy
serial disappointer Xchanging was followed by its £57m acquisition of 2.2% margin
reseller Trustmarque. The conference call led us to believe that the resellers causing
the problem were those acquired since 2008 and not Trustmarque acquisition (so the
Trustmarque warning, presumably, has yet to come).

BE

Valuation still too high. Forget earnings. Whatever consensus settles at, it will be
wrong. No-one can guess the pipeline conversion rate attrition spot businesses
better than the aggregate cumulative error in all three, so let’s not pretend that we
can. Instead, let’s assume that CPI can generate FCF of a bit more in 2017 than it did
last year. This puts it on a FCF yield of 7.6%. Is this cheap? BAB’s sits on 7.8% and has
far fewer risks. So no, it isn’t. BAB’s gearing is 1.3x despite a 6% hit from weak sterling
v 2.7x for CPI. On a 10% FCF yield, CPI’s shares would trade at 530p, which becomes
our new TP (23% downside). Back to sell.

BE

............ which is an excellent note, to my mind.

11:22 am
BE

We've also got Shore selling.

BE

Brexit a catalyst? Whilst we have harboured concerns in our research for some time over the level of growth driven by acquisitions, sustainable margins and growing debt levels, we were nonetheless surprised by the timing of yesterday’s profits warning. The specific’s and ‘one-offs’ that Capita point to as being primarily responsible only point to some of the issues that the group faces in our view, but these still point to some worrying strategic failures. We are particularly concerned by what we consider to be under-investment in organic development, such as in the education platform and addressing the digital opportunity in recruitment and sourcing – has this been at the expense of prioritising acquisitive growth? We view Capita as a services conglomerate following the disparate acquisitive activity of the last several years (we note the group has acquired c£2.0bn in revenue since FY2010, with revised revenues forecast for this year now at £4.9n, group revenues in FY2011 were £2.9bn). We believe that effective service delivery needs focus, but it can be scaled, as Capita has shown in the past. Looking to ‘Brexit’ as being a cause of Capita’s woes, our view is that this has likely hasted and accelerated trends already in play in the business.
Margins and the outlook. That margins are now some 100bps+ off prior guidance is our focus, with a margin recovery next year the prime mover for a return to profits growth. Capita is now guiding to a quieter period for acquisitions with a focus on debt repayment. The business does generate cash at a strong underlying rate, but we note that significant restructuring charges may now follow through FY2017F and we are concerned over costs being reduced to increase margins at the expense of service delivery and so future growth; i.e. will a recovery be sustainable without a much deeper change and evolution programme? Visibility on the out-turn for FY2017F is now very clouded with none beyond this, in our opinion. We believe that returning margins to the 14% level on a sustainable basis reflects only a historic view of the business and outsourcing market, ignoring current and likely future competitive realities.

BE

Forecast downgrades. Our FY2016F EPS expectation falls from 73.8p to 65.4p (-11%) and for FY2017F from 76.4p to 68.0p (-11%) – we believe that risk is at a heightened level on these revised forecasts as business conditions and the need for restructuring continues. We now restrain our dividend growth assumptions, seeing flat progression from this point, keeping cover to 2.0x through next year. We note Capita’s ability to pay an increased dividend in theory from holding company reserves, but note that at the consolidated level a likely material increase in the pensions deficit (our estimate c£360m by December 2016) and potential goodwill write-offs diminish reserves in subsidiaries in consolidation – possibly leading some internal restructuring?
Capita is now trading on a FY2017F PER of 10.4x (EV/EBITDA 8.9x) on our revised forecast with a free cash flow yield of c5.8% and offering a dividend yield of 4.6%. Not expensive then, but we perceive uncertainty of direction and risk. Our fundamental thought is that this is one to avoid for the foreseeable future, we move to SELL.

11:24 am
BE

Incidentally, I remember Stifel flagging up back in March that Capita was highly vulnerable from the increasing use of framework agreements.

BE

As in, you can win a government contract but you don't get any kind of guarantee of the level of work it'll provide.

PM

That seems a bit tough

11:25 am
BE

Historically, it might be argued, outsourcing services companies have relied quite a bit on mispriced contracts.

PM

Well yes

BE

As in, you lose money on nine deals you underbid for, then make it up on the one where margins were mispriced by government rather than your own sales team.

11:26 am
BE

Framework agreements seem to help fix the latter without changing the former.

BE

Morgan Stanley takes a walk through the sector this morning, and buys Babcock.

BE

Profit warnings from MITIE and Capita raise concerns over
outsourcers' organic growth and margins. Directionally
outsourcers' organic growth have trended together, but endmarkets
differ and we continue to prefer Babcock's more
resilient exposure to defence

11:29 am
BE

BE

While outsourcers' growth trends
directionally, Babcock's organic growth has remained most resilient through the
cycle and should remain so. c.80% of its business is exposed to UK defence,
nuclear, marine and emergency services (police and fire) vs, peers 4-30%. We
expect CY16 organic growth of +6.4% vs. Serco -11.7% and Capita now guiding to
+1%.

Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 1,019, down 27 (-2.58%), High: 1,039, Low: 1,018, Volume: 699.56k
11:29 am
undefined
PM

Markets Live

PM

We might mention the GDP figs this morning

11:30 am
BE

Oh, sure.

PM

Britain in better shape than we thought

PM

Here's a bit of Barclays

11:30 am
PM

GDP: Somewhat more resilient than anticipated

· Pre-referendum economic activity was slightly stronger than we and consensus had first anticipated. Headline GDP growth for Q2 16 was revised up 0.1pp to 0.7% q/q given upward revisions to construction output (+0.6pp to -0.1% q/q, which we had previously flagged would pose upside risks to headline GDP growth) as well as an upward revision to services output (+0.1pp to 0.6% q/q).

· Activity appears to have remained somewhat resilient in July, immediately after the referendum. July services output accelerated to 0.4% m/m, from 0.3% m/m in June, resulting in a Q3 16 carry-over for services output of 0.6% q/q, unchanged from Q2 16. Consequently, the total aggregate output (services, industrial production and construction) carry-over for Q3 16 is 0.4% q/q. This contrasts with our and consensus forecasts of 0.0% q/q growth and the BoE forecast of 0.3% q/q as of the September MPC minutes (the BoE had forecast 0.1% q/q in the August 2016 Inflation Report).

PM

More resilient output than anticipated immediately after the referendum, coupled with August and September surveys showing improving firm and household sentiment, suggest that upside risks to our Q3 16 GDP forecast appear to be materialising. That said, we only have one month of official data, and will have to wait until the preliminary release of Q3 16 GDP on 27 October 2016 which will comprise official data for July and August as well as ONS estimates for September. While we maintain our call for a cut of 20bp in the Bank Rate at the November 2016 MPC meeting, given the risks to our growth profile highlighted above, we acknowledge the likelihood of a cut decreases marginally. Overall, the MPC decision will be finely-balanced in our view; there still appears to be appetite for another cut given the minutes of the September MPC meeting as well as comments made by Committee member Minouche Shafik on 28 September 2016, although it is likely to be conditional on further slowing in economic activity.

PM

Oh and look, we're well-er than we maybe thought

11:31 am
PM

ONS...

PM

In Quarter 2 (April to June) 2016, gross domestic product (GDP) per head increased 0.5% compared with Quarter 1 (January to March) 2016 and is now 1.3% above pre-economic downturn levels. This was a slightly slower growth rate than the 0.7% quarterly increase seen in GDP.

Net national disposable income (NNDI) per head increased by 0.4% in Quarter 2 2016 compared with the same quarter a year ago. Growth in NNDI per head in Quarter 2 2016 was lower than GDP per head over the same period. This was due to a continued deterioration in the balance of earnings on direct investment, which moved from a surplus of £2.8 billion to a deficit of £2.0 billion between Quarter 2 2015 and Quarter 2 2016.

In Quarter 2 2016, real household disposable income (RHDI) per head excluding non-profit institutions serving households (NPISH), increased 2.0% compared with the same quarter a year ago. Growth was largely driven by increases in net social benefits other than transfers in kind, wages and salaries, and gross operating surplus including gross mixed income.

Household spending per head also increased in Quarter 2 2016 (2.2%) compared with the same quarter a year ago (Quarter 2 2015). This continues the general upward trend seen since Quarter 3 (July to September) 2011, but it remains 0.9% below pre-economic downturn levels.

The provisional estimate of median household disposable income for the financial year ending 2016 is £26,400, an estimated increase of £700 from financial year ending 2015, after accounting for inflation and household composition, and £400 higher than its pre-downturn value of £26,000 in the financial year ending 2008.

PM

https://www.ons.go...er2apriltojune2016

11:31 am
PM

Total median wealth in those households with a Household Reference Person (HRP) aged between 55 and 64 increased 11.5% and for those 65 and over 14.9% between July 2010 to June 2012 and July 2012 to June 2014. This compares to a 13.8% decrease for those aged between 16 and 24.

By Quarter 2 2016, the inactivity rate had declined by 1.8 percentage points from its 2011 average of 23.3%. This decline was mainly driven by a decrease in the number of people reporting they were inactive due to early retirement, long-term sickness, and looking after the family and home.

PM

Economic well-being stats

undefined
11:32 am
PM

But given the Capita stuff etc, why is Serco up?

Serco Group PLC (SRP:LSE): Last: 132.90, up 2.5 (+1.92%), High: 133.20, Low: 127.70, Volume: 783.34k
BE

I've literally no idea.

11:33 am
BE

Nothing I've seen since it was named preferred bidder on Barts NHS Trust, which was about a week ago.

BE

(And if one wants a contract with very little upside and unlimited potential for reputational damage, taking over the running of St Barts' catastrophically mismanaged Trust seems ideal.)

BE

(@DRichi: noted. Though since I lost my login after the first week I've taken quite a passive approach thus far.)

11:36 am
undefined
PM

Deutsche stock still very much at sale prices -- 10.34 to buy now

BE

(@jimpj: Indeed. Look at the board of NHS Improvement. It genuinely made me lol.)

11:37 am
BE

Not investment advice

BE

What else, then? Revisit DMGT?

Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 738.50, up 9.5 (+1.30%), High: 746.50, Low: 721.00, Volume: 536.06k
11:38 am
PM

If you like

PM

What's the new angle?

BE

Panmure very much likes the idea of them sacking all their journalists.

11:39 am
BE

Which I think was the unstated upshot of yesterday's £50m exceptional.

PM

Depriving us of 'Get me out of here': Khloe Kardashian sizzles in sheer lacy teddy and ripped jeans as she jets out of LAX amid family drama

PM

(Boncoeur -- I don't get every call right. Admitted)

11:40 am
BE

Well, that's the question really. It's whether Mail Online would be bundled into the Mail newspaper, with its voluminous daily coverage of LSE and Deutsche Bank.

BE

And more importantly, whether Dacre would accept such a thing.

PM

You're quietly sacking Dacre here, are you?

11:41 am
BE

NO! I'm absolutely not sacking Dacre!

PM

Not even after the poisonous things he wrote about M. Lionel??

PM

Well, he didn't write them

11:42 am
PM

But we guess commissioned

BE

I don't have much of an opinion on newspaper editors being nasty to each other. It happens many strata above my daily existence.

PM

(Boncoeur -- you'll not with that link that you are immediately served with an advert, giving you the opportunity to buy the same Khloe lacy teddy thing. It's a shabby business, 'news')

11:44 am
BE

Can I get back to Panmure, telling us to buy the DMGT? That, I think, is where we came in. Before you tried to suggest I was in effect sacking the most dangerous and volatile man in our chosen profession. ..................

PM

omg smile

BE

Here's the gist.

11:44 am
BE

New CEO Paul Zwillenberg (in place since
June 1st) made an unexpected appearance on the call, and offered some initial views
on strategy ahead of a more detailed update with the prelims (December 1st). The
strategic direction he pointed towards is likely to drive a more sustained period of
positive newsflow for the shares, in our view. Specifically he indicated: (1) moving
from investment phase to delivery phase (delivering on the revenue and profit
potential of the portfolio, following several years of heavy investment in several areas
including RMS(one), MailOnline, Hobsons, property and energy information); (2)
focusing on operational execution (again delivering on investment, but also possibly
implying no major M&A required, in particular to broaden out MailOnline); (3) a
strategic review of the whole portfolio, to create greater focus. To assist all this, the
group now expects to incur an exceptional restructuring charge of £50m for the year,
rather than the previously indicated £15m. We do not expect a radical shake-up of
the portfolio: Zwillenberg referenced the benefit of diversity (much prized by the
controlling shareholder, The Viscount Rothermere) and making “a few tweaks” to the
portfolio going forward. Nevertheless, this could be enough to drive a re-rating of the
portfolio from current undemanding levels, in our view.

BE

Valuation is attractive following a long period of underperformance for the shares, at
around 13x EPS and 9x EBITDA, assuming unchanged Sep17E estimates. The balance
sheet is sound (ND/EBITDA forecast to be 1.8x at year end, with net debt of c£600m
and further potential liquidity in the form of a 31% stake in Zoopla (worth over £400m
currently) and a 68% stake in Euromoney (worth nearly £1bn). We also see good
valuation support from our Sum Of the Parts analysis. Our last published SOTP (730p)
rises to around 780p if we mark-to-market for the current valuations of Zoopla,
Euromoney and key peers: and further to around 825p if we reduce our holding
company discount assumption from 15% to 10% (SOTP c920p before any discount).
All this is based on FY16E forecasts and multiples.

BE

And I'm kinda sorry I mentioned it now.

11:45 am
undefined
BE

Corporate rather light today.

BE

At least among the big stuff. There's an E1 trading update to mention, I guess.

11:46 am
Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 216.10, up 3 (+1.41%), High: 217.70, Low: 208.60, Volume: 304.84k
BE

In line with expectations, on track for full year.

BE

Film might not be as bad as ..... usual.

11:47 am
BE

Which is on The BFG and Now You See Me 2.

PM

I thought BFG was a complete flop

BE

No idea.

11:48 am
BE

"More whizzpopper than gobblefunk" says Investec's Steve Liechti. If you can stomach that kind of thing.

BE

Net positive 1H/AGM update with trading good/as expected and expectations for FY underlying performance unchanged. TV and Family momentum remain strong and Film box office performance is much better with a more healthy looking slate. New library valuation at $1.5bn highlights Entertainment One’s content value creation against its EV, even after allowing for the Peppa step-up. Valuation still attractive versus content peers – CY17E adj. EV/EBITDA 7.7x and P/E c.10x, adj. FCF yield of 6%.

BE

Forecasts U/R – outlook unchanged/positive with no material changes to underlying forecasts expected, but FX mark to market should boost consensus EPS by c. +4%. FY17/18E EPS 18.7p/21.5p vs FactSet 19p/22p.
TV momentum. ETO is still targeting 1100 half hours in the FY (FY16A: 998), with a swathe of drama re-commissions and a strong 2H pipeline. International distribution also looks strong.
Mark Gordon accelerating – new series, Designated Survivor, premiered strongly on ABC with ‘very strong’ international sales. The second new series, Conviction, is in production. Five older high profile MGC series have been re-commissioned.
Family – Peppa is positive internationally with US merchandise demand above expectations. The new 52 episode series is delivered this year. PJ Masks sounds very interesting, with US merchandise now launching.
Film – higher profile, bigger films are driving box office sales at $151m to date (+56%) on a lower number of titles (85 vs 96). Big releases such as The BFG have done well (£30m UK box office) with a stronger 2H slate. A positive front catalogue performance bodes well for outer year window/catalogue sales.
Catalogue value – new independent valuation is $1.5bn at 31/3/2016 ($1bn before) with c. $300m increase from the Peppa step-up and revaluation. This implies an additional $200m of net catalogue value despite recent film woes. ETO has used a new valuation agency (Salem Partners) so numbers are not strictly comparable, but a WACC of 8.2% (previously 8.3%) and overhead allocation at 6% are consistent.

11:49 am
BE

The independent catalogue valuation is a new thing to me. Treating an archive of Peppa Pig shorts as oil estimates or something.

BE

Has it always done that? Or is this in response to the ITV takeover approach?

BE

Singer are sellers. As usual.

11:50 am
BE

There is the usual lack of detail in the ETO H1 statement however trading appears to be good enough to support their indication that they are trading in-line at an underlying level. If this is correct then an FX tailwind will add to existing consensus forecasts by c3-4%. ETO has provided the usual annual update on library valuation and the headline looks strong at US$1.5bn even allowing for the Peppa Pig stake acquisition. The library valuation however no longer appears to be the rock underpinning value that we had considered it to be. The valuation has not been carried out by an independent (too a degree understandable this year given the bulk of financing is through the bond issue) and the last values that have been provided use ETO’s own inputs and a much lower WACC (c8% vs c11-12%). This doesn’t help the weak cash flow picture in our view. We have put our forecasts under review at this stage. The stock had a big boost from the ITV approach (c236p) and effectively this will probably provide support around the 200p. The shares don’t look particularly good value from this perspective and less so on fundamentals due to weak cash flow and now a questionable library valuation.

BE

Okay, so the library valuation was because the banks on the hook for its debt refi demanded it.

BE

As Singer says ...........

11:52 am
BE

When ETO updated the market in 2015 the value issued was NOT the bank valuation it was a modified valuation using its WACC input c8% vs previously WACC of c11-12%. We were unaware of this step change in the method applied. ETO has appointed a new valuer this year again using their inputs.

BE

Hm.

PM

wot?

11:53 am
BE

Yeah, I'm in unfamiliar territory here ...........

BE

Perhaps it's best to just disregard it entirely.

BE

Which is what Peel Hunt does.

11:53 am
BE

It is
tempting to consider the £1.15bn library value , less £0.37bn debt to give a net
value of c £0.8bn which, compared to an equity value of £0.9bn, suggests that all
the infrastructure is in there for free. However, without a much fuller
understanding of how the library value is derived and exactly what it comprises
we see this calculation being of limited value.

BE

And the top line ..........

BE

H1 trading has been in line with previous trends continuing.
Film is recovering from a weak period, TV strong (Mark Gordon
is the prize asset) and Peppa Pig making brand headway in
China. Overall there is a need to reflect some modest currency
gains – 3-4% for the current and future years. The figure that
will drive headlines is the reported library value of $1.5bn, up
from $1.0bn. However, without granularity on its composition
and derivation its value as a metric is constrained. Having
received one tentative approach at 236p there is nothing in this
statement to change the attractiveness of this asset to a bidder.
Absent a bid, we remain comfortable with a 200p TP and Hold

Housebuilders very weak yesterday on the back of the mortgage data, and no little confusion about Help To Buy after several news services took no news as news.

12:01 pm
BE

This is as per the falling rate of mortgage approvals, and the impossibility to read trends into the data given how much government mucks about with policy.

BE

It might appear logical to assume that if the number of buyers is falling, that a buyers’ market would begin to form and that house price inflation would decline, if not reverse. Yet there is little or no sign of this and although the most comprehensive house price index (Land Registry) has shown a small deceleration in its latest data, the rate of annual inflation is still reported to be 8.3%. This looks to be due to the market remaining broadly in balance with a weakness in buyers largely matched by a lack of sellers (according to the RICS).

Therefore, it is likely that inflation is being fuelled by the steady drop in mortgage rates and the general loosening of mortgage lending policies (more high LTV lending, greater numbers of higher LTI advances and lengthening of mortgage maturities). If purchasing power of buyers is increased and there is no evident increase in the supply of homes for sale, it is unsurprising that buyers would be inclined to push pricing ahead.

Pricing of mortgages appears set to continue falling in our view, and perhaps accelerate as the price of wholesale funds for lenders has dropped (via the Term Funding Scheme), competition looks to have increased, BREXIT does not appear to have materially altered lenders’ attitude to risk and there are fewer buyers looking to take out a mortgage. This creates fertile ground for a price war and we note that the FCA recently reported that it has increased scrutiny of the mortgage market through concerns over a ‘race to the bottom’ on mortgage rates.

BE

So, it's all about subprime lending and nothing about demand.

12:03 pm
BE

Earlier in 2016 we raised concerns about what appeared to be a rapid loosening of lending policy in the mortgage market and an apparent reduction in the perception of lending risk. This loosening was focused on prime lending but through the likes of the re-introduction of 100% mortgages and 40 year mortgages for first time buyers, lenders looked to be beginning to pursue less prime buyers.

BE

This looks to have stepped up and we see early signs of what could be a re-emergence of sub-prime lending. Recently we have seen the Aldermore Family Guarantee Mortgage, the Cambridge Building Society product range for what it calls ‘mortgage misfits’ and the FCA’s comments that outside the ‘big six’ mortgage lenders: “We are starting to see sub-prime and a tolerance of poor payment histories”.

If demand is shrinking, most likely we believe because of a raw lack of affordability and a lack of equity creation for those looking to move on to larger premises, loosening core lending has failed to ignite demand and relatively lower risk buy-to-let lending has reduced, it is almost inevitably that lenders would begin to look at increasingly fringe borrowers. In such a low interest rate environment, even lending with a greater risk premium means that the actual rate the borrower pays is still low by historical standards. The Cambridge product, for example, offers two year money at 5.99% and the Aldermore product is priced at 5.48% for a 100% LTV. According to the Bank of England, the average price for a 2 year fixed rate 95% LTV mortgage in August was 3.99% making costs for riskier mortgage only around 20% more expensive in monthly payments than the mainstream product.

BE

So ...................

12:04 pm
BE

While the wider housing market appears to be solidly in reverse, the house builders continue to report that it’s ‘business as usual’ and that BREXIT has had no impact on demand. What is visible is that the use of help to buy is creeping up steadily with some of the larger builders potentially testing 50% usage on their open market sales: 40% or more is becoming the norm against a figure closer to 33% only a year ago. Help to buy does give a significant advantage to the new homes market and would support what appears to be a sizeable increase in market share: borrowing an effective 75% while only putting down a 5% deposit means that mortgage payments are around 25% lower than for a straight 95% LTV loan. Add in factor such as new homes being naturally top-of-chain, potentially chain-free if part-exchange is offered and in a tightening market, new build does begin to appear more attractive.

While new build’s overall share of the housing market does appear to be increasing, we also believe that the share of the quoted house builders within the new build market is also likely to be increasing. There have been reports recently that the larger SME house builders are finding it increasingly hard to find sites to acquire. The changes in the planning environment under the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) have increased the supply of land materially but this has been achieved to a greater extent by granting permission on much large sites. Only the large house builders are really in a position to buy such sites. If market share has been taken from the SMEs, there is a risk that a revitalisation of other channels for new build (through changes in policy) could mean that activity levels of the larger house builders begin to reflect the weaker trends seen in mortgage data as market share re-balances.

So, a key question has to be how long can the house builders continue to trade against what is turning into a well-established weakening of demand in the wider housing market? That depends very much on policy decisions that will begin to become more apparent through the Conservative Party conference and in the Autumn Statement in late November. Help to buy has potentially become such a large distortion in the housing market that action could begin to be taken against it. While there is a broad promise that the scheme will run through until 2021, what form it takes could change: the upper limits on value could be reduced, it could be geographically limited or the level of equity investment made by the government (now 20% nationally and 40% in London) could be stepped down progressively. A progressive winding down of help to buy would help to avoid a financial ‘cliff’ if the scheme ends suddenly in five years time and the inevitable scramble to take advantage of it as the end approaches.

BE

Robin Hardy at Shore is by a country mile the best of the housing sellside analysts.
